paths.title: IUI With Partner Sperm
paths.description: Intrauterine insemination using sperm from your partner - available as natural cycle (OPK monitoring) or medicated cycle (trigger shot protocol)
paths.suitable_for: Couples with unexplained infertility, mild male factor, or ovulation issues

steps.overview: You'll have an initial consultation with your fertility specialist to discuss your goals, review your medical history, and create a personalized treatment plan. This appointment allows your doctor to understand your situation, explain the iui with partner sperm process, discuss success rates specific to your age and diagnosis, and answer all your questions. You'll also complete required fertility testing to assess your reproductive health and determine the best approach.
Choose between natural cycle monitoring (tracking your own ovulation) or medicated cycle (using fertility medications). Complete baseline assessment to confirm you are ready to start treatment.

Your clinic tracks your cycle through monitoring appointments (ultrasounds and bloodwork) to determine the optimal timing for your procedure. If using medications, you'll take fertility drugs to stimulate egg development and receive a trigger shot when follicles are mature. This monitoring ensures eggs are retrieved or insemination occurs at exactly the right time for the best chance of success.

On the day of your IUI procedure, sperm is collected from your partner (fresh sample) or thawed from a donor/cryopreserved sample. The lab then prepares the sperm through a washing and concentration process that separates the healthiest, most motile sperm from seminal fluid. This prepared sperm is then placed directly into your uterus through a thin catheter in a quick, painless intrauterine insemination (IUI) procedure, bypassing the cervix and giving sperm a head start toward the egg.

Wait approximately two weeks after the IUI, then return for a blood pregnancy test. Your doctor will discuss next steps based on the results, whether continuing treatment or transitioning to prenatal care.

paths.title: IUI With Donor Sperm
paths.description: Intrauterine insemination using donor sperm - available as natural cycle (OPK monitoring) or medicated cycle (trigger shot protocol)
paths.suitable_for: Single individuals, same-sex couples, or severe male factor infertility

steps.overview: You'll have an initial consultation with your fertility specialist to discuss your goals, review your medical history, and create a personalized treatment plan. This appointment allows your doctor to understand your situation, explain the iui with donor sperm process, discuss success rates specific to your age and diagnosis, and answer all your questions. You'll also complete required fertility testing to assess your reproductive health and determine the best approach.

You'll review and select a sperm donor from a donor bank or sperm bank database. You can search by physical characteristics, medical history, education, and other criteria that are important to you. Required counseling helps you understand the emotional and legal aspects of using donor sperm. Once you select a donor, the clinic orders the sperm samples for your treatment cycle.

This prepared sperm is then placed directly into your uterus through a thin catheter in a quick, painless intrauterine insemination (IUI) procedure, bypassing the cervix and giving sperm a head start toward the egg.

paths.title: IVF With Own Eggs & Partner Sperm
paths.description: In vitro fertilization using your own eggs and partner sperm, with fertilization method (conventional or ICSI) determined by your doctor based on sperm quality and other factors
paths.suitable_for: Couples with tubal factor, endometriosis, male factor infertility, failed IUI, or unexplained infertility who are using their own fresh eggs and partner sperm

steps.overview: You'll have an initial consultation with your fertility specialist to discuss your goals, review your medical history, and create a personalized treatment plan. This appointment allows your doctor to understand your situation, explain the ivf with own eggs & partner sperm process, discuss success rates specific to your age and diagnosis, and answer all your questions. You'll also complete required fertility testing to assess your reproductive health and determine the best approach.
Your doctor selects the best medication protocol for your situation. Complete baseline ultrasound and bloodwork to confirm you are ready to start. Learn how to administer your fertility medications.

You'll take daily fertility medication injections (gonadotropins) for 8-12 days to stimulate your ovaries to produce multiple eggs instead of the single egg released in a natural cycle. Having multiple eggs increases the chances of successful fertilization and embryo development. You'll attend frequent monitoring appointments (every 2-3 days) where ultrasounds track follicle growth and blood tests measure hormone levels, allowing your doctor to adjust medication dosages for optimal egg development.
When your eggs are mature (follicles reach 17-20mm), you will receive a precisely-timed trigger shot to complete final egg maturation. Egg retrieval is scheduled exactly 35-36 hours later.

Under light sedation, your doctor uses ultrasound guidance to retrieve eggs from your ovaries through a thin needle. The procedure takes 15-30 minutes. You will rest in recovery for 1-2 hours before going home.

Sperm is collected and prepared. Mature eggs are fertilized using conventional IVF (mixing sperm and eggs together). The next day, the embryologist checks to see how many eggs fertilized successfully.

Fertilized eggs (now embryos) are cultured in the lab for 3-6 days to allow them to develop and reach optimal transfer stage. The embryology team monitors their growth daily and grades their quality to help select the best embryo(s) for transfer. This observation period helps identify which embryos have the best developmental potential. You may also choose genetic testing (PGT) during this time.

Your doctor selects the best quality embryo(s) and transfers it into your uterus using a thin catheter under ultrasound guidance. This is a quick, painless procedure. Any remaining good-quality embryos are frozen for future use.
topic_refs: Fresh Embryo Transfer - Day Five (Blastocyst Stage)

steps.overview: Begin progesterone supplementation to support the uterine lining. Wait 9-14 days after transfer, then return for a blood pregnancy test. If pregnant, you will have early monitoring ultrasounds before graduating to regular prenatal care.

paths.title: IVF With Personal Eggs & Donor Sperm
paths.description: IVF using your own eggs and donor sperm - includes protocol selection (GnRH antagonist vs agonist), mandatory counseling, and conventional IVF fertilization (preferred over ICSI for donor sperm)
paths.suitable_for: Single individuals or couples with severe male factor infertility

steps.overview: You'll have an initial consultation with your fertility specialist to discuss your goals, review your medical history, and create a personalized treatment plan. This appointment allows your doctor to understand your situation, explain the ivf with personal eggs & donor sperm process, discuss success rates specific to your age and diagnosis, and answer all your questions. You'll also complete required fertility testing to assess your reproductive health and determine the best approach.

You'll complete required infectious disease screening and sign informed consent documents to ensure you understand the treatment process and risks. These screenings protect both you and any future pregnancy, while the consent process ensures you're making fully informed decisions. This is a required step before proceeding with any fertility treatment.
Provide a semen sample through ejaculation in a private collection room. If needed, multiple samples can be collected on different days to maximize the amount of sperm stored.

You'll complete storage consent forms and arrange payment for ongoing storage fees to maintain your frozen sperm samples safely. Your sperm can remain frozen indefinitely while maintaining viability. When you're ready to use your frozen sperm for fertility treatment (IUI, IVF, or ICI), contact the clinic to schedule a consultation. At that time, your doctor will help you select the best treatment approach based on your partner's fertility status and your family-building goals.

paths.title: IVF With Donor Eggs
paths.description: IVF using eggs from a donor - available as fresh donor cycle (synchronization required) or frozen donor eggs (no synchronization). ICSI required for frozen eggs, mandatory counseling and legal representation.
paths.suitable_for: Advanced maternal age, poor egg quality, diminished ovarian reserve, or genetic concerns

steps.overview: You'll have an initial consultation with your fertility specialist to discuss your goals, review your medical history, and create a personalized treatment plan. This appointment allows your doctor to understand your situation, explain the ivf with donor eggs process, discuss success rates specific to your age and diagnosis, and answer all your questions. You'll also complete required fertility testing to assess your reproductive health and determine the best approach.

Complete infectious disease screening and sign legal contracts establishing parental rights. Your clinic will coordinate with the egg donor (if using fresh eggs) or prepare frozen eggs for your cycle.

Take estrogen and progesterone medications to prepare your uterine lining for embryo implantation. Your clinic monitors lining thickness through ultrasound to ensure optimal conditions. This happens while your donor undergoes stimulation (fresh) or while eggs are thawed (frozen).

Fertilized eggs (now embryos) are cultured in the lab for 3-6 days to allow them to develop and reach optimal transfer stage. The embryology team monitors their growth daily and grades their quality to help select the best embryo(s) for transfer. This observation period helps identify which embryos have the best developmental potential. You may also choose genetic testing (PGT) during this time.

One or more embryos are transferred to your uterus in a quick, painless procedure guided by ultrasound. Any remaining quality embryos can be frozen for future use. You'll continue progesterone support medications after transfer.

After the two-week wait, you'll return for a blood pregnancy test (beta hCG) to determine if embryo implantation was successful. This blood test is more accurate than home urine tests and can detect pregnancy earlier. If positive, you'll continue medications to support early pregnancy and have follow-up monitoring. If negative, your doctor will discuss next steps and any adjustments for future cycles.

paths.title: Double Donation IVF
paths.description: IVF using both donor eggs and donor sperm - includes genetic matching between donors to prevent 300+ genetic diseases. Highest success rates with 98% cumulative pregnancy rate after 3 cycles. ICSI required for optimal fertilization.
paths.suitable_for: Couples with both partners having fertility issues, same-sex couples, single individuals, or genetic concerns requiring dual donor screening

Your doctor selects the best quality embryo(s) and transfers it into your uterus using a thin catheter under ultrasound guidance. This is a quick, painless procedure. Any remaining good-quality embryos are frozen for future use.

Continue taking progesterone and any other prescribed medications to support potential implantation during the two-week wait. Approximately 9-12 days after embryo transfer, you'll return for a blood pregnancy test (beta hCG). If positive, you'll continue medications to support early pregnancy and have follow-up ultrasounds to confirm heartbeat before graduating to regular prenatal care. If negative, your doctor will discuss next steps, including whether to try another cycle or explore other options.

paths.suitable_for: Same-sex female couples wanting both partners involved biologically, LGBTQ+ couples seeking shared motherhood experience

paths.title: Sperm Freezing
paths.description: Preserve male fertility by freezing sperm
paths.suitable_for: Before cancer treatment, vasectomy, or advancing age

steps.overview: You'll have an initial consultation with your fertility specialist to discuss your goals, review your medical history, and create a personalized treatment plan. This appointment allows your doctor to understand your situation, explain the sperm freezing process, discuss success rates specific to your age and diagnosis, and answer all your questions. You'll also complete required fertility testing to assess your reproductive health and determine the best approach.

You'll complete required infectious disease screening and sign informed consent documents to ensure you understand the treatment process and risks. These screenings protect both you and any future pregnancy, while the consent process ensures you're making fully informed decisions. This is a required step before proceeding with any fertility treatment.
Provide a semen sample through ejaculation in a private collection room. If needed, multiple samples can be collected on different days to maximize the amount of sperm stored.

Your sperm sample is analyzed for count, motility, and morphology to assess quality. The sample is then divided into multiple vials and frozen using a controlled-rate freezing process or vitrification to preserve sperm viability. Frozen sperm is stored in liquid nitrogen tanks at -196°C where it can remain viable indefinitely. You'll complete storage consent forms and arrange for annual storage fees. When you're ready to use your frozen sperm for fertility treatment (IUI or IVF), contact the clinic to schedule a consultation to determine the best treatment approach.

paths.title: Egg Freezing
paths.description: Preserve fertility by freezing unfertilized eggs
paths.suitable_for: Delaying childbearing, before cancer treatment, or medical conditions

steps.overview: You'll have an initial consultation with your fertility specialist to discuss your goals, review your medical history, and create a personalized treatment plan. This appointment allows your doctor to understand your situation, explain the egg freezing process, discuss success rates specific to your age and diagnosis, and answer all your questions. You'll also complete required fertility testing to assess your reproductive health and determine the best approach.

You'll complete required infectious disease screening and sign informed consent documents to ensure you understand the treatment process and risks. These screenings protect both you and any future pregnancy, while the consent process ensures you're making fully informed decisions. This is a required step before proceeding with any fertility treatment.

You'll take daily fertility medication injections (gonadotropins) for 8-12 days to stimulate your ovaries to produce multiple eggs instead of the single egg released in a natural cycle. Having multiple eggs increases the chances of successful fertilization and embryo development. You'll attend frequent monitoring appointments (every 2-3 days) where ultrasounds track follicle growth and blood tests measure hormone levels, allowing your doctor to adjust medication dosages for optimal egg development.
Under light sedation, your doctor uses ultrasound guidance to retrieve eggs from your ovaries through a thin needle. The procedure takes 15-30 minutes, followed by 1-2 hours of recovery time.

Eggs are immediately frozen using vitrification, an ultra-rapid freezing technique that prevents ice crystal formation and maximizes egg survival rates. Each egg is carefully frozen and stored in liquid nitrogen at -196°C where they can remain viable for many years. You'll receive a report on how many mature eggs were successfully frozen. Storage consent forms and annual fees ensure your eggs remain safely preserved until you're ready to use them.

You'll complete storage consent forms and arrange payment for ongoing storage fees to maintain your frozen eggs safely. Eggs can remain frozen indefinitely while maintaining viability. When you're ready to use your frozen eggs to try for pregnancy, contact the clinic to schedule a consultation. You'll then go through the egg thawing, fertilization (with partner or donor sperm), and embryo transfer process to attempt pregnancy using your preserved fertility.

paths.title: Embryo Freezing With Partner
paths.description: Create and freeze embryos with partner's sperm
paths.suitable_for: Couples planning to delay pregnancy

steps.overview: You'll have an initial consultation with your fertility specialist to discuss your goals, review your medical history, and create a personalized treatment plan. This appointment allows your doctor to understand your situation, explain the embryo freezing with partner process, discuss success rates specific to your age and diagnosis, and answer all your questions. You'll also complete required fertility testing to assess your reproductive health and determine the best approach.

You'll complete required infectious disease screening and sign informed consent documents to ensure you understand the treatment process and risks. These screenings protect both you and any future pregnancy, while the consent process ensures you're making fully informed decisions. This is a required step before proceeding with any fertility treatment.
Provide a semen sample through ejaculation in a private collection room. If needed, multiple samples can be collected on different days to maximize the amount of sperm stored.

Embryos are frozen using vitrification at either day 3 (cleavage stage) or day 5-6 (blastocyst stage) of development. This ultra-rapid freezing technique preserves embryo quality for future use. You'll complete storage consent forms specifying how long to store embryos, annual storage fees, and what should happen to embryos in various scenarios. Frozen embryos can be stored indefinitely and thawed for future Frozen Embryo Transfer (FET) cycles. When you're ready to attempt pregnancy, contact the clinic to schedule an FET consultation.

paths.title: Emergency Fertility Preservation
paths.description: Rapid preservation before cancer treatment
paths.suitable_for: Cancer patients needing immediate treatment

steps.overview: You'll have an urgent consultation with a fertility specialist who coordinates with your oncology team to balance cancer treatment timing with fertility preservation. This rapid assessment determines what fertility preservation options are possible given your cancer diagnosis, treatment timeline, and current health status. Required infectious disease screening is fast-tracked, and your doctor explains the time-sensitive nature of preserving fertility before cancer treatment begins. This coordination ensures you can pursue fertility preservation without delaying critical cancer treatment.

Start fertility medications immediately using a "random-start" protocol (can begin any day of your cycle). Daily monitoring to optimize egg development while minimizing delays to your cancer treatment. Trigger shot when ready.
Priority scheduling for egg retrieval (under sedation) or sperm collection (in private room). Same-day processing to minimize time before starting cancer treatment.

Your eggs, sperm, or embryos are immediately frozen using vitrification and stored securely. All storage documentation is expedited so you can return to cancer treatment without delay. Your frozen materials will remain safe indefinitely in storage. After you've completed cancer treatment and recovery, and when you're ready to build your family, contact the fertility clinic to schedule a consultation about using your preserved fertility. The clinic will guide you through the appropriate pathway (FET for embryos, egg thawing and fertilization for eggs, or IUI/IVF for sperm) when the time is right.

paths.title: Ovarian Tissue Cryopreservation
paths.description: Experimental preservation of ovarian tissue
paths.suitable_for: Prepubertal girls or when time doesn't allow for egg freezing

steps.overview: You'll have an initial consultation with your fertility specialist to discuss your goals, review your medical history, and create a personalized treatment plan. This appointment allows your doctor to understand your situation, explain the ovarian tissue cryopreservation process, discuss success rates specific to your age and diagnosis, and answer all your questions. You'll also complete required fertility testing to assess your reproductive health and determine the best approach.

You'll complete required infectious disease screening and sign informed consent documents to ensure you understand the treatment process and risks. These screenings protect both you and any future pregnancy, while the consent process ensures you're making fully informed decisions. This is a required step before proceeding with any fertility treatment.

Your partner provides a sperm sample (or donor sperm is thawed) which is then processed in the lab to select the healthiest, most motile sperm. This preparation process, called washing and concentration, separates the best sperm from seminal fluid and debris, increasing the chances of successful fertilization or insemination.
Eggs are assessed for maturity and quality. Mature eggs are immediately flash-frozen using vitrification (ultra-rapid freezing) to maximize survival rates when thawed in the future.

You'll complete storage consent forms and arrange payment for ongoing storage fees to maintain your frozen ovarian tissue safely. The tissue will remain in cryogenic storage until you're ready to use it. When you've completed your medical treatment and are ready to pursue fertility, contact the clinic to discuss ovarian tissue transplantation or egg maturation options. Your doctor will assess the best approach for using your preserved tissue based on advances in reproductive medicine and your individual circumstances.

paths.description: Emergency embryo creation and cryopreservation using partner sperm with random-start ovarian stimulation for women requiring urgent cancer treatment within 2-4 weeks
paths.suitable_for: Women with committed male partners diagnosed with cancer requiring chemotherapy or radiation that may compromise ovarian function

steps.overview: You'll have an urgent consultation with a fertility specialist who coordinates with your oncology team to balance cancer treatment timing with fertility preservation. This rapid assessment determines what fertility preservation options are possible given your cancer diagnosis, treatment timeline, and current health status. Required infectious disease screening is fast-tracked, and your doctor explains the time-sensitive nature of preserving fertility before cancer treatment begins. This coordination ensures you can pursue fertility preservation without delaying critical cancer treatment.

Start fertility medications immediately using a "random-start" protocol (can begin any day of your cycle). Daily monitoring to optimize egg development while minimizing delays to your cancer treatment. Trigger shot when ready.

Embryos are frozen using vitrification at either day 3 (cleavage stage) or day 5-6 (blastocyst stage) of development. This ultra-rapid freezing technique preserves embryo quality for future use. You'll complete storage consent forms specifying how long to store embryos, annual storage fees, and what should happen to embryos in various scenarios. Frozen embryos can be stored indefinitely and thawed for future frozen embryo transfer (FET) cycles.

Once your fertility preservation is complete, you can proceed immediately with your cancer treatment without delay. Your fertility specialist coordinates with your oncology team to ensure a smooth transition and confirms that all preserved materials are safely stored. Your frozen eggs, sperm, or embryos will remain viable indefinitely in storage. After you've completed cancer treatment and recovery, and when you're ready to build your family, contact the fertility clinic to schedule a consultation about using your preserved fertility. The clinic will guide you through the next steps when the time is right.

paths.suitable_for: Single women diagnosed with cancer or women whose partners cannot participate in fertility preservation requiring chemotherapy or radiation within 2-4 weeks

paths.suitable_for: Prepubertal girls and women requiring immediate cancer treatment who cannot delay for ovarian stimulation or who have cancers excluding other preservation methods

paths.title: Frozen Embryo Transfer (FET) Cycle
paths.description: Transfer previously frozen embryos using your own or a gestational carrier's uterus. This is one of the most common IVF cycle types, used when embryos were frozen from a previous cycle or after genetic testing.
paths.suitable_for: Patients with frozen embryos from a previous IVF cycle, those who did elective freezing ('freeze-all'), or those who completed genetic testing on embryos

steps.overview: Schedule a consultation with your fertility doctor to review your frozen embryos, discuss the transfer plan, and update any medical history. Your doctor will review embryo quality, recommend how many to transfer, and create a personalized medication protocol.

Take prescribed medications (typically estrogen and progesterone) to prepare your uterine lining for embryo implantation. Your clinic will monitor your lining thickness through ultrasounds to ensure optimal conditions for transfer.

Once your uterine lining reaches the ideal thickness (usually 8mm+), your transfer date will be scheduled. You'll receive specific instructions about when to start progesterone support and what to do on transfer day.

On transfer day, the embryology lab will thaw your embryo(s). The transfer procedure is quick and typically painless, similar to a pap smear. The embryo(s) are placed into your uterus using a thin catheter guided by ultrasound.

Continue taking progesterone and any other prescribed medications to support potential implantation. This is called the 'two-week wait' - the time between transfer and your pregnancy test. Follow all medication instructions carefully during this critical time.

Approximately 9-12 days after transfer, you'll have a blood test to check for pregnancy (beta hCG test). If positive, you'll continue medications and have repeat blood tests and ultrasounds. If negative, your doctor will discuss next steps.

paths.title: Using Your Frozen Eggs
paths.description: Ready to use the eggs you previously froze? This pathway guides you through thawing your eggs, fertilization, and transferring the resulting embryos. Whether you froze eggs for medical or elective reasons, this is your roadmap to using them.
paths.suitable_for: Patients who previously froze eggs and are now ready to attempt pregnancy

steps.overview: Schedule a consultation with your fertility doctor to discuss using your frozen eggs. Review your medical history, update any health changes since freezing, and discuss sperm source options. Your doctor will explain success rates based on your age at freezing and number of eggs available.

You'll decide on your sperm source - partner sperm, donor sperm from a bank, or a known donor - as this determines the genetic makeup of your future child. If using partner sperm, your partner will provide a fresh sample or you may already have sperm frozen. If using donor sperm, you'll select a donor and complete necessary legal paperwork. This decision-making step ensures you have the sperm source secured before thawing your precious frozen eggs, as eggs must be used immediately once thawed.

The embryology lab will carefully thaw your frozen eggs. ICSI (intracytoplasmic sperm injection) is typically used to fertilize thawed eggs, as it has higher success rates than conventional fertilization. Your clinic will report how many eggs survived the thaw and were successfully fertilized.

Fertilized eggs (now embryos) will be cultured in the lab for 3-6 days. The embryology team monitors their development and grades them for quality. You may choose to do genetic testing (PGT) on embryos before transfer.

While embryos develop, you'll take medications to prepare your uterine lining. Once ready, one or more embryos will be transferred into your uterus in a quick, usually painless procedure. Any remaining quality embryos can be frozen for future use.

After the two-week wait, you'll return for a blood pregnancy test (beta hCG) to determine if embryo implantation was successful. This blood test is more accurate than home urine tests and can detect pregnancy earlier. If positive, you'll continue medications to support early pregnancy and have follow-up monitoring. If negative, your doctor will discuss next steps and any adjustments for future cycles.

paths.title: Using Your Frozen Sperm
paths.description: Use sperm you previously froze for fertility treatment. This pathway helps you coordinate thawing your frozen sperm with your partner's cycle for IUI or IVF treatment.
paths.suitable_for: Patients with previously frozen sperm who are ready to use it for fertility treatment with a partner or gestational carrier

steps.overview: Schedule a consultation with your fertility doctor to discuss using your frozen sperm. Review your sperm analysis from the time of freezing, discuss treatment options (IUI vs IVF), and create a plan coordinated with your partner's cycle.

Based on your partner's fertility evaluation and your sperm parameters, your doctor will recommend either IUI or IVF to maximize your chances of success with your frozen sperm. IUI may be appropriate if your partner has open fallopian tubes and regular cycles, while IVF is recommended for more complex cases or if sperm count/quality is limited. This assessment ensures you choose the treatment approach that gives you the best chance of pregnancy while making the most of your stored sperm samples.

Your partner will begin cycle monitoring or ovarian stimulation depending on whether you're doing IUI or IVF, as her cycle must be synchronized with the sperm thaw and procedure timing. The clinic tracks her follicle development and coordinates the timing of when to thaw your sperm sample with either her insemination date (IUI) or egg retrieval (IVF). This precise coordination is essential because thawed sperm must be used fresh and cannot be refrozen, so timing is critical for success.

On the day of your partner's IUI or egg retrieval, the lab will thaw your frozen sperm sample. The sperm will be washed and prepared for insemination or fertilization. The lab will assess post-thaw sperm quality and quantity.

For IUI: Prepared sperm is placed directly into your partner's uterus. For IVF: Sperm is used to fertilize eggs in the lab, typically using ICSI if sperm count is limited. Your clinic will guide you through the specific pathway you've chosen.

After the two-week wait, you'll return for a blood pregnancy test (beta hCG) to determine if embryo implantation was successful. This blood test is more accurate than home urine tests and can detect pregnancy earlier. If positive, you'll continue medications to support early pregnancy and have follow-up monitoring. If negative, your doctor will discuss next steps and any adjustments for future cycles.

paths.title: Transitioning from IUI to IVF
paths.description: Moving from IUI to IVF is one of the most common transitions in fertility treatment. This pathway helps you understand why your doctor is recommending IVF, what to expect, and how to prepare for the next phase of your journey.
paths.suitable_for: Patients who have attempted IUI (usually 3-6 cycles) without success and are considering or have been recommended to move to IVF

steps.overview: Failed IUI cycles don't mean you did anything wrong. Many factors affect IUI success, including timing, egg quality, sperm quality, and unknown factors. Your doctor will review your IUI cycles to identify any patterns and explain why IVF may offer better chances given your specific situation.

IVF provides greater control and visibility than IUI, which is why your doctor recommends this next step. With IVF, fertilization happens in the lab where it can be observed and documented, embryos can be graded and tested for genetic issues, and the best embryo(s) are selected for transfer. This increased control helps address the factors that may have prevented success with IUI, improving your chances of pregnancy and allowing your doctor to identify and overcome specific fertility challenges.

IVF is a significant financial investment. Meet with your clinic's financial counselor to understand costs, review insurance coverage, explore payment plans, and learn about medication assistance programs. Understanding the financial picture upfront helps you plan and reduces stress.

Schedule an IVF consultation to create your personalized treatment plan. Your doctor may order additional testing such as updated hormone levels, antral follicle count, or genetic carrier screening. This is also the time to ask all your questions about the IVF process.

Your care team will create a customized IVF protocol based on your age, ovarian reserve, and previous treatment response. You'll learn about your medication protocol, how to do injections, what to expect during monitoring appointments, and timeline for your cycle.

Once you're ready emotionally and financially, and all testing is complete, you'll start your first IVF cycle. Your clinic will coordinate timing with your menstrual cycle and provide detailed instructions for your specific protocol. You'll follow one of the standard IVF pathways depending on your situation (own eggs with partner sperm, donor sperm, etc.). The IVF process typically includes ovarian stimulation, egg retrieval, fertilization, embryo development, and transfer, taking 4-6 weeks from start to pregnancy test. Your care team will walk you through each step with renewed hope and a treatment approach designed to overcome the challenges you faced with IUI.

paths.title: Transitioning to Donor Eggs After Failed IVF
paths.description: After multiple unsuccessful IVF cycles with your own eggs, moving to donor eggs can be an emotionally complex decision. This pathway provides guidance on understanding donor egg options, making informed decisions, and preparing for this next phase of your journey.
paths.suitable_for: Patients who have had unsuccessful IVF cycles with their own eggs and are considering or have been recommended to use donor eggs

steps.overview: Meet with your doctor to discuss why donor eggs are being recommended and understand the success rates. Donor egg IVF typically has higher success rates because the eggs come from younger donors, but it represents a significant shift in your journey that deserves thoughtful consideration.

You'll need to decide between using an anonymous donor from an agency/bank, or a known donor (friend or family member). Each option has different medical, legal, emotional, and logistical considerations. Your clinic can help you understand the pros and cons of each approach.

Donor egg IVF involves additional costs beyond standard IVF, including donor compensation, agency fees, legal contracts, and sometimes donor medications. Meet with a financial counselor to understand all costs and explore financing options. Some insurance plans provide limited coverage.

Donor egg arrangements require legal contracts to establish parental rights and outline all parties' responsibilities. You'll work with a reproductive attorney to ensure proper documentation, whether using a known or anonymous donor. This step protects everyone involved.

If using an anonymous donor, you'll review donor profiles including physical characteristics, medical history, education, and sometimes photos or personal essays. If using a known donor, they'll undergo medical and psychological screening. Take time to find the right match for your family.

Once your donor is selected and all legal/medical clearances are complete, you'll begin the donor egg IVF cycle following the 'IVF With Donor Eggs' pathway. If using fresh donor eggs, your clinic will coordinate your endometrial preparation with your donor's ovarian stimulation. If using frozen donor eggs, you'll start medications to prepare your uterine lining while the clinic thaws and fertilizes the eggs. You'll then proceed through embryo development, transfer, and pregnancy testing. Your care team will guide you through each remaining step of your donor egg journey, providing both medical and emotional support.

paths.title: Egg Freezing for Transgender Men
paths.description: Preserve your fertility options before starting testosterone therapy or other gender-affirming treatments. This pathway is designed specifically for transgender men (assigned female at birth) who want to freeze eggs before medical transition.
paths.suitable_for: Transgender men who have not yet started testosterone therapy and wish to preserve fertility before beginning gender-affirming hormone treatment

steps.overview: You'll have an initial consultation with your fertility specialist to discuss your goals, review your medical history, and create a personalized treatment plan. This appointment allows your doctor to understand your situation, explain the egg freezing for transgender men process, discuss success rates specific to your age and diagnosis, and answer all your questions. You'll also complete required fertility testing to assess your reproductive health and determine the best approach.
topic_refs: Before Gender-Affirming Hormone Therapy or Surgery

steps.overview: Your fertility clinic will coordinate with your endocrinologist or gender care provider to ensure the egg freezing cycle doesn't interfere with your transition plans. If you've already started testosterone, you may need to temporarily pause it before the egg freezing cycle.
topic_refs: Before Gender-Affirming Hormone Therapy or Surgery

steps.overview: Complete fertility testing to assess your ovarian reserve and overall reproductive health. This includes bloodwork (AMH, FSH, estradiol) and an ultrasound to count follicles. These tests determine your expected response to ovarian stimulation medications.

You'll take daily fertility medication injections (gonadotropins) for 8-12 days to stimulate your ovaries to produce multiple eggs instead of the single egg released in a natural cycle. Having multiple eggs increases the chances of successful fertilization and embryo development. You'll attend frequent monitoring appointments (every 2-3 days) where ultrasounds track follicle growth and blood tests measure hormone levels, allowing your doctor to adjust medication dosages for optimal egg development.

When follicles are mature, you'll have the egg retrieval procedure under light sedation. A doctor uses ultrasound guidance to collect eggs from your ovaries through the vaginal wall. The procedure takes about 20-30 minutes, and you'll go home the same day.

Eggs are immediately frozen using vitrification, an ultra-rapid freezing technique that prevents ice crystal formation and maximizes egg survival rates. Each egg is carefully frozen and stored in liquid nitrogen at -196°C where they can remain viable for many years. You'll receive a report on how many mature eggs were successfully frozen. Storage consent forms and annual fees ensure your eggs remain safely preserved until you're ready to use them.

After recovery from egg retrieval (typically 1-2 weeks), you can proceed with starting or resuming testosterone therapy and other gender-affirming treatments. Your eggs are safely stored and can be used in the future if you decide to pursue biological parenthood.
topic_refs: Before Gender-Affirming Hormone Therapy or Surgery
